title: How to Take Blood Pressure Manually

steps.title: Verify that you have the right cuff size.
steps.content: Verify that you have the right cuff size. A standard size blood pressure cuff purchased from a drugstore will fit around the arm of most adults. However, if you have an especially narrow or wide arm, or if you plan to take the blood pressure of a child, you may need a different size. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The cuff should be wide enough to cover 40-80% of the distance from your elbow to shoulder and long enough to cover 75-100% of the distance around your arm. Check the size of a cuff before buying it. Look at the "index" line. This is the range line on the cuff that tells you if it fits. Once it is on the patient's arm it will tell you whether or not the circumference of your arm fits within the "range" area of the cuff. [2] X Research source If you do not use the proper cuff size, you may end up with an inaccurate measurement.

steps.title: Avoid factors that can increase your blood pressure.
steps.content: Avoid factors that can increase your blood pressure. Certain conditions can cause your blood pressure to spike temporarily. In order to get an accurate measurement, you or your patient should avoid these conditions before taking your blood pressure. Factors that can affect blood pressure include: stress, smoking, exercise, cold temperatures, a full stomach, a full bladder, caffeine, and some medications. [3] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source Your blood pressure can change throughout the course of the day. If you need to check it regularly, try to do so at the same approximate time each day. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source

steps.title: Find a quiet place.
steps.content: Find a quiet place. You will need to listen to your (or your patient's) heartbeat, so a quiet setting is ideal. A quiet room is also a calm room, so someone who rests in a quiet room while checking their blood pressure is more likely to feel relaxed, rather than stressed. Therefore, you are more likely to get an accurate reading. [5] X Trustworthy Source Pan American Health Organization Health information and news provided by the Pan American Health Organization, the regional office of the World Health Organization for the Americas. Go to source

steps.title: Get comfortable.
steps.content: Get comfortable. Because physical stress can affect a blood pressure reading, you or the patient whose reading youâ€™re taking should get comfortable. For example, use the bathroom before you have your blood pressure taken. [6] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source It's also a good idea to keep yourself warm. Find a warm room, or if the room is chilly, wear an extra layer of clothing to keep warm. In addition, if you have a headache or body ache, try to reduce or relieve the pain before taking your blood pressure.

steps.title: Remove tight sleeves.
steps.content: Remove tight sleeves. Roll up your sleeve or change into a shirt that exposes your upper arm since blood pressure cannot accurately be taken over clothing. Blood pressure can be measured from either arm, so you can choose which arm to use. [7] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source

steps.title: Rest for 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.content: Rest for 5 to 10 minutes. Resting will assure that your heart rate and blood pressure have the chance to stabilize before the measurement is taken. [8] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Find a comfortable and appropriate location to take your blood pressure.
steps.content: Find a comfortable and appropriate location to take your blood pressure. Sit in a chair next to a table. Rest your forearm on the table so that it rests at about heart level. Keep the palm of your hand facing up and your feet flat on the floor. [9] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source Sit up straight. Your back should be against the back of the chair and your legs should be uncrossed. Use a supportive seat, like a dining room chair, rather than a couch or sofa.

steps.title: Locate your pulse.
steps.content: Locate your pulse. Place your index and middle fingers over the inside center of your inner elbow. When you press lightly you should be able to feel the pulse of your brachial artery from this position. [10] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you have difficulty locating your pulse , place the head of a stethoscope (the round piece at the end of the tube) in the same general area and listen until you can hear your heartbeat.

steps.title: Wrap the cuff around your arm.
steps.content: Wrap the cuff around your arm. Tuck the cuff end through the metal loop and slide it onto your upper arm. The cuff should be roughly 1 inch (2.5 cm) above the bend of your elbow and should be evenly tight around your arm. [11] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Make sure that your skin is not pinched by the cuff as you wrap it securely. The cuff should have a heavy duty hook-and-loop fastener on it, which will hold the cuff closed.

steps.title: Check the tightness of the cuff by slipping two fingertips underneath.
steps.content: Check the tightness of the cuff by slipping two fingertips underneath. If you can wiggle the two fingertips under the top edge but cannot wedge your full fingers beneath the cuff, the cuff is tight enough. If you can wedge your full fingers under the cuff then you need to open up the cuff and pull it tighter before closing it again. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Slide the head of a stethoscope under the cuff.
steps.content: Slide the head of a stethoscope under the cuff. The head should be face down, with the wide part of the chest piece in contact with the skin. It should be positioned directly over the pulse of your brachial artery that you found earlier. [13] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Also place the stethoscope earpieces in your ears. The earpieces should face forward and point toward the tip of your nose.

steps.title: Position the gauge and the pump.
steps.content: Position the gauge and the pump. The gauge needs to be positioned where you can see it. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Hold the gauge lightly in the palm of your hand if taking your own blood pressure. If taking someone else's blood pressure, you can hold the gauge in whatever position you want as long as you can see the face of the gauge clearly. Turn the screw on the pump bulb clockwise to close the airflow valve, if necessary.

steps.title: Inflate the cuff.
steps.content: Inflate the cuff. Rapidly squeeze the pump bulb until you no longer hear the sound of your pulse through the stethoscope . [15] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Stop once the gauge reads 30 above your normal blood pressure. [16] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source If you do not know your normal blood pressure, inflate the cuff until the gauge reads between 160 to 180 mmHg.

steps.title: Deflate the cuff.
steps.content: Deflate the cuff. Open the airflow valve by twisting the screw counterclockwise. Let the cuff deflate gradually. [17] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The gauge should fall 2 mm, or two lines on the gauge, per second.

steps.title: Listen for the systolic reading.
steps.content: Listen for the systolic reading. Note the measurement on your gauge at the precise moment you hear your heartbeat again. [18] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This measurement is your systolic reading. Systolic blood pressure refers to the force your blood exerts against the artery walls as your heart pumps. [19] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source This is the blood pressure created when your heart contracts.

steps.title: Listen for the diastolic reading.
steps.content: Listen for the diastolic reading. Note the measurement on your gauge at the precise moment the sound of your heartbeat disappears. [20] X Research source This measurement is your diastolic reading. Diastolic blood pressure refers to your blood pressure in between heartbeats. [21] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Rest and repeat the test.
steps.content: Rest and repeat the test. Let the cuff completely deflate. After several minutes, follow the same steps to take another measurement. If your blood pressure is still high, consider comparing readings with the other arm. [22] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Mistakes can happen while taking your blood pressure, especially if you are not used to doing it. As such, it is important to double-check your findings by taking a second measurement.

steps.title: Know what normal blood pressure should be.
steps.content: Know what normal blood pressure should be. For an adult, the systolic blood pressure should be less than 120 mmHg and the diastolic blood pressure should be less than 80 mmHg. [23] X Trustworthy Source American Heart Association Leading nonprofit that funds medical research and public education Go to source This range is considered "normal." Healthy behaviors, including diet and exercise, should be maintained in order to maintain this blood pressure range.

steps.title: Catch signs of prehypertension (elevated blood pressure).
steps.content: Catch signs of prehypertension (elevated blood pressure). Prehypertension is not necessarily dangerous by itself, but someone with prehypertension is at risk of experiencing hypertension in the future. An adult in a state of prehypertension will have a systolic blood pressure between 120 and 129 mmHG and a diastolic blood pressure between 80 and 79 mmHg when you read the results . [24] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Talk to a health care professional about making changes to your diet and lifestyle in order to drop your blood pressure.

steps.title: Detect signs of stage 1 hypertension.
steps.content: Detect signs of stage 1 hypertension. During state 1 hypertension, also known simply as high blood pressure, an adult's systolic blood pressure is between 130 and 139 mmHg. The diastolic blood pressure is between 80 and 89 mmHg. [25] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Hypertension requires professional medical care. Schedule an appointment with your doctor so that he or she may prescribe an appropriate hypertension medication.

steps.title: Assess whether you have stage 2 hypertension (high blood pressure).
steps.content: Assess whether you have stage 2 hypertension (high blood pressure). This is a serious condition and requires prompt medical care. If your systolic blood pressure is at or above 140 mmHg and your diastolic blood pressure is at or above 90 mmHG, you have stage 2 hypertension. [26] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Understand that blood pressure can also be too low.
steps.content: Understand that blood pressure can also be too low. If your systolic blood pressure stays around 90 mmHg and your diastolic blood pressure remains around 60 mmHG, your blood pressure may be too low. Symptoms of low blood pressure include lightheadedness, fainting spells, dehydration, lack of concentration, vision problems, nausea, fatigue, depression, rapid breathing, and clammy skin. [27] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Talk with your doctor to discuss possible reasons behind your drop in blood pressure and possible ways to raise it to normal levels.

steps.title: Consult a physician if you suspect you have hypertension or low blood pressure.
steps.content: Consult a physician if you suspect you have hypertension or low blood pressure . Your doctor will retest your blood pressure to make sure your readings are accurate. If you do have hypertension, or prehypertension, your doctor will make recommendations for lowering your blood pressure . This will include lifestyle changes, if you have prehypertension, in addition to medication if you have actual hypertension. [28] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source The doctor may also test for other conditions that hinder normal blood pressure, especially if the patient is already on medication. If you are already on medication for your blood pressure, your doctor may suggest therapy or consider testing for additional health problems that prevent the medication from working properly.
